Her business is conducted in the area known as "16th of July", a central location in the city where a large part of the administrative and commercial offices are located.  The city has a cold and dry climate with a temperature that varies between 0 and 12 degrees Celsius.  

Ema has brown skin, brown eyes, long dark hair pulled back, and is thin and of lower height.  Her native language is Aymará which she speaks at home, and Spanish which she speaks in the culture at large and for her business.  She lives with her children who are in school.  They live in a rented room made of brick and cement with a zinc roof and a wood floor.  They have potable water, electricity, gas and plumbing.  Her business involves selling second-hand clothing for women such as jackets, rain coats, sweaters, blouses, shirts, etc.  She works in a fixed open-air stall six days per week.  She sells seasonal clothing: "I began my business when I was very young, with the help of my parents.  I acquired a fixed stall which is the only source of income for my family."  The advantage of her business is that clothing sells year round.  The disadvantage is that she lacks capital in order to invest and grow her business.  

Her dream is to have a stall with a roof.  She wants to invest in her business by buying second hand clothing for winter in bulk.  This is her first loan sequence with Kiva's field partner in the six years she has been working in this field.  Ema is seeking a loan in order to buy women's second hand clothing in order to use the income to support her business by putting a roof on her stall.

loans.use: to buy women's second hand clothing in order to use the income to support her business by putting a roof on her stall.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy: laminated sheets, wood, and nails to replace the roof on her house.

loans.name: Salu Women Group

texts.en:
Esther, the lady raising her hand in the photo is a member of the Salu Women Group. She is 52 years old, married and blessed with six children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2014 to benefit from trainings, especially enterprise development. 

She is a farmer and taking a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and certified seeds. This will enable her boost her crop production and income enabling her to pay for her family's house renovation and expenses for quality health care. 

Esther is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and certified seeds.

loans.name: Zephaniah

texts.en:
Zephaniah is a married and has two children, ages 4 and 6. He lives in the Kiminini area of Kenya and owns a 1.5 acre of land he uses to farm. He keeps a dairy cow and 13 heads of poultry. 

His main sources of income are milk and from poultry, he gets eggs and meat for family consumption. 

Zephaniah is seeking a loan to start commercial poultry farming.  He intends to use this loan to buy traditional breeds of chicken that are adapted to local conditions. He wants to take advantage of the growing demand for poultry products in the market. 

Zephaniah will use the income that he hopes to earn to look after his family’s well-being and their children’s education. He also wants to continue investing in poultry.

loans.use: to start a poultry business.

loans.name: Katindo Kaseo Dip W.g Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Annah, age 30. She is married and blessed with two children; one attends school. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 to benefit from the trainings, especially enterprise development.

Annah is a poultry farmer and taking a Kiva loan to buy more chickens to add to her stock of eggs and chickens for sale.  With increased income, she will pay for her family's expenses, like food and clothing. 

Annah is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy more chickens.

loans.name: Ngwate Ngutwike S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Martha, a member of Ngwate Ngutwike S.H.Group. She is 35 years old, married and a mother of three children. 

She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HIH EA) in 2013 to benefit from the trainings and especially enterprise development.

Martha owns and operates a green house where she practices vegetables farming. 

She is borrowing from Kiva to buy fertilizer and pesticides to boost her vegetable production. With increased income, she will be able to meet her family's needs such as food, medical and school fees. 

Martha is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Fidel

texts.es:
Fidel, de 47 años de edad, es una persona luchadora, a pesar de su discapacidad en una de sus manos es un agricultor, pescador y es miembro activo del comité de crédito de credicampo, está casado y vive con su esposa y sus 5 hijos. 
Fidel, tiene una larga trayectoria en la actividad agrícola, ya que siempre realiza sus siembras con el objetivo de comercializar granos básicos y también para dar alimentación a su familia, además se ha dedicado a la pesca en un rio.

Fidel, necesita el crédito para comprar insumos agrícolas como abono, pesticidas y herbicidas para preparar las tierras y obtener una buena cosecha.

Fidel, planea comprar un motor para su lancha, para tener acceso a otras zonas para incrementar la pesca y comercializar el pescado.
texts.en:
47 year old Fidel is a hardworking person in spite of a disability in one of his hands. He is a farmer and fisherman and is an active member of the loan committee for Credicampo. He is married and lives with his wife and their 5 children.
Fidel has been a farmer for a long time. He always sows his crops with the goal of selling staple grains and also of providing food for his family. He also works fishing in a river. 
Fidel needs a loan to buy agricultural supplies such as fertilizer, pesticides, and herbicides to prepare the land and secure a good harvest. 
Fidel plans to buy a motor for his boat so that he can get to other parts of the river to increase his fishing catch and sales of fish.

loans.use: to buy agricultura supplies such as fertilizer, pesticides, and herbicides to prepare the land and secure a good harvest.

loans.name: Kyeni Kya Kamuthini Women Group

texts.en:
The name of the lady raising her hand in the photo is Reginah; 42 years old, married with three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2013 to benefit from the training, especially enterprise development. 

She operates a kiosk and is taking a Kiva loan to buy more foodstuffs like sugar, cooking fat and wheat flour, to add stock to satisfy her customers' needs.

Reginah is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the financial support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
The lady in the photo is Susan. She is 69 years old, married and a mother of eight. 

She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the 2013 and her main business is vegetable farming. 

Susan is grateful to Hand in Hand Eastern Africa for its training on enterprise and financial management that has enabled her improve the management of her business. 

She is borrowing from Kiva to buy quality fertilizer so that she can increase her output and increase her profits.

Susan is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Valley Hope Women Group

texts.en:
The lady raising hand in the photo is Esther, a member of the Valley Hope women group. She is 56 years old, married and a mother of four. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013.

She owns a retail shop selling food stuffs and is grateful for Hand in Hand Eastern Africa’s training on enterprise and financial management that has enabled her manage her business well. 

Esther is borrowing from Kiva to buy more stock for her shop to hopefully increase her sales and profits.

She is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to buy more stock of food stuffs.

loans.name: Leonardo Dacio

texts.es:
Leonardo es un hombre de 40 años de edad, casado, tiene 2 hijos de 3 y 13 años y 2 hijas de 1 y 18 años, y su negocio es la fabricación de estuches geométricos.
Él es buen padre, emprendedor, independiente, constante, responsable y muy trabajador. Su negocio lo desarrolla en la zona ‘16 de julio’ dónde se lleva a cabo la feria comercial más grande del país, los días jueves y domingo desde tempranas horas de la mañana, feria en la que se puede encontrar cualquier tipo de cosas que se necesite.
Leonardo es de tez morena, ojos pardos usa lentes de aumento, cabello negro corto, baja estatura, complexión física mediana, su lengua materna es el Aymará que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con esposa que se dedica a la venta de comida y con sus hijos; la mayor ya termino la escuela, el segundo hijo estudia en la escuela y los 2 menores aún no se encuentran en edad escolar, viven en una casa propia construida de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de madera que cuenta con los servicios de agua potable, energía eléctrica, gas domiciliario y alcantarillado. Su negocio es la fabricación de estuches geométricos para profesores y sastres estos sirven para dibujar figuras geométricas planas, de trazos rectilíneos o curvos y consta de: Regla graduada, Escuadra, Transportador y Compás, “inicié mi oficio como ayudante en una empresa que se dedica a la fabricación de juegos didácticos, ahí conocí mis clientes y logré independizarme…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con clientes contantes, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de madera y otros materiales necesarios para la producción. Su sueño es ser vendedor mayorista, él desea realizar la compra de materia prima para la fabricación de pizarras acrílicas. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 10 años que desarrolla esta actividad independientemente.
Es por esos motivos que Leonardo solicita un préstamo para la compra de materia prima para la fabricación de pizarras para vender por mayor a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Leonardo is a 40-year-old man, married. He has 2 sons of 3 and 13 years and 2 daughters of 1 and 18 years. His business is the manufacture of geometric cases. He is a good father, enterprising, independent, consistent, responsible, and very hardworking. He develops his business in the "16 de julio" [July 16] area, where the country's largest trade fair takes place Thursdays and Sundays from early hours of the morning, a fair where any kind of things needed can be found.

Leonardo has dark complexion and brown eyes, uses magnifying glasses, has short black hair, and is of short stature and medium physique. His mother tongue is Aymara, which he speaks among family, and speaks Spanish because of general culture and the business he does. He shares his life with his wife who sells food, and his children; the oldest girl already finished school, the second son is studying in school and the 2 youngest are not yet of school age. They live in a home of their own, built of brick and cement with a tin roof and wooden floor that features water, electricity, domestic gas, and sewerage services. 

His business is the production of geometric cases for teachers and tailors. These serve to draw plane and straight or curved lines geometric figures and comprise graduated rulers, squares, protractors, and compasses. "I started my job as an assistant in a company that manufactures educational games. There, I met my customers and managed to become independent...", he says. The advantage of his business is that he has consistent customers; the disadvantage is the lack of capital for the purchase of wood and other materials needed for the production. His dream is to become a wholesaler. 

He wants to make the purchase of raw materials for the manufacture of whiteboards. This is the first cycle of loans with the institution in the 10 years he has independently developed this occupation. It is for these reasons Leonardo is requesting a loan, for the purchase of raw materials for the manufacture of boards to sell wholesale to his customers.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for the manufacture of boards to sell wholesale to his customers.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias comes from a rural area in Kiera village in Kenya, where he has fertile land for agriculture. 

His wife and two children love dairy farming. For the milk, they get food and income. Elias started dairying seven years ago. Today, he has three cows, three goats and about a dozen heads of poultry. 

Elias sells raw milk at the local market and uses the income to cover domestic and business expenses.
  
Through hard work and sacrifices, Elias has grown his dairy farm over the years. He is seeking a loan to grow more. The borrowed money will be used to buy an additional dairy cow which will reproduce calves and produce more milk for him to sell. 

Your loan investment will help Elias grow his business and income to elevate the living standard of his family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.
